title: 111_s114
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Center for Social Work Research Act". The findings of Congress highlight the role of social workers in improving individual and family functioning, providing prevention and treatment services in various areas, and offering valuable research on complex social issues. Establishment of National Center for Social Work Research under Section 401(a) of the Public Health Service Act to focus on research in social work. The National Center for Social Work Research conducts and supports targeted research on social work methods and outcomes related to significant social issues. It aims to promote research and training to inform social work practices and provide policymakers with research information to better understand complex social issues and make informed funding decisions. The Director of the National Center for Social Work Research may provide research training, fellowships, and stipends to individuals studying disease prevention, health promotion, social work care, child abuse, neglect, and youth violence in underserved populations and areas. The Director of the Center may provide grants to nonprofit institutions for training, instruction, and fellowships with stipends and allowances as determined necessary. The Director of the Center may provide grants to nonprofit institutions for training, instruction, and fellowships with stipends and allowances as determined necessary. SEC. 485K. ADVISORY COUNCIL. The Secretary will establish an advisory council for the Center to advise on activities, accept gifts, and make research recommendations. The Center may review research applications, recommend projects for approval, review grants and agreements, collect information on studies, and make information available through publications. The advisory council for the Center may appoint subcommittees, convene workshops, and consist of ex officio members including key officials from various organizations. The advisory council for the Center may appoint subcommittees and consist of key officials from various organizations, as well as additional officers or employees as determined necessary by the Secretary for effective functioning. The Secretary appoints up to 18 individuals to the advisory council for the Center, with a focus on health and scientific disciplines, including social workers and leaders in public policy and law. The Secretary appoints up to 18 individuals to the advisory council for the Center, including leaders in public policy, law, health policy, economics, and management. Members do not receive compensation if they are officers or employees of the United States, while others receive compensation not exceeding the daily equivalent of the maximum rate for a GS-15 position. Terms of office for members are staggered to avoid all expiring in the same year. The term of office for members appointed to the advisory council is 4 years, with the possibility of serving until a successor is appointed. Reappointments are not allowed within 2 years of the prior term's expiration. Vacancies must be filled within 90 days by the Secretary. The chairperson of the advisory council is selected by the Secretary from among the members appointed under subsection (b)(3) or the Director of the Center. The chairperson serves a 2-year term and the council must meet at least 3 times each fiscal year. The Director designates an executive secretary for the council. The Director of the Center provides staff and assistance to the advisory council. New members receive orientation and training for effective participation. The advisory council can make comments and recommendations in the biennial report regarding its activities, the Center's progress, and future directions. The advisory council may prepare additional reports as deemed appropriate. The Director of the Center, in consultation with the advisory council, will prepare a biennial report for inclusion in the overall report, detailing the Center's activities and program policies. Additionally, the Director will submit quarterly reports to Congress summarizing research findings and policy implications.
